item.title: Ticket #9301 (no classes on div-coment in Walker_Comment::start_el()) updated
item.dc:creator: docwhat
item.description: Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #9301 (no classes on div-coment in Walker_Comment::start_el()) updated
item.dc:creator: docwhat
item.description:
Example Patch 

diff --git a/wp-includes/comment-template.php b/wp-includes/comment-template.php
index a4a126b..49cdfc1 100644
--- a/wp-includes/comment-template.php
+++ b/wp-includes/comment-template.php
@@ -1221,3 +1221,3 @@ class Walker_Comment extends Walker {
                <?php if ( 'ul' == $args['style'] ) : ?>
-               <div id="div-comment-<?php comment_ID() ?>">
+               <div id="div-comment-<?php comment_ID() ?>" class="comment-body">
                <?php endif; ?>

item.title: Ticket #9301 (no classes on div-coment in Walker_Comment::start_el()) created
item.dc:creator: docwhat
item.description:
There are no classes on Walker_Comment::start_el() when it creates a <div id="div-comment-NNNN"> node.

This makes using CSS target that node pretty hard if not impossible across browsers.

Ideally, it would have a class like "comment-body".

This is a feature aid semantic markup.

item.title: Ticket #9069 (Function get_comment_link returns duplicate URLs for comments ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
I've been thinking about this more and I think that always having the page number in the URL is a good thing. What if you decide you want the latest comments to be shown first rather than the oldest? Then /example-post/#comment-1 wouldn't work.

A filter on the output would be a good idea though.

item.title: Ticket #9262 (Incorrect behaviour with using the PRE tag when switching between ...) closed
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
invalid:

Viper007Bond is right. Also <code> is an inline tag that has no special meaning in HTML. According to W3C the browsers "may choose" to display it with fixed width font, nothing else.

The <pre> tag has special meaning. It displays line breaks as they appear in the source. It can include most inline elements (​http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/sgml/dtd.html#pre.exclusion). It doesn't escape and cannot contain bad/invalid HTML tags.

item.title: Ticket #9300 (WP_Query with posts_per_page and sticky posts) created
item.dc:creator: yukataninja
item.description:
When using WP_Query with showposts=some_number and you have one post set as a sticky that is out of the range of some_number, the query returned will have some_number plus one posts returned. If the sticky post is within the range of some_number then only some_number of posts is returned by WP_Query.

Example Normal: have 3 posts in order: Post 1, Post 2, Post 3

my_WPQuery = new WP_Query("showposts=2");

This will return Post 1 and Post 2

Example Error: have 3 posts in order: Post 1, Post 2, Post 3 (<-- make sticky)

my_WPQuery = new WP_Query("showposts=2");

This will return 3 posts (Post 3, Post 1, Post 2).

Expected to return 2 posts (Post 3, Post 1).

Example OK: have 3 posts in order: Post 1, Post 2 (<-- make sticky), Post 3

my_WPQuery = new WP_Query("showposts=2");

This will return 2 posts (Post 2, Post 1).

item.title: Ticket #9280 (<guid isPermaLink> never ever true) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
OK you win as I see on ​http://cyber.law.harvard.edu/rss/rss.html .

Gee, they had to tie unique message IDs to URLs. Usenet beats that.

I'll tell those aforementioned GMANE chumps...

item.title: Ticket #9280 (<guid isPermaLink> never ever true) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description: Ref: ​http://feedvalidator.org/docs/error/InvalidPermalink.html

item.title: Ticket #9280 (<guid isPermaLink> never ever true) closed
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
invalid:

I'm afraid we're talking about two different meanings of 'permalink', the index.php?... meaning, and the RSS GUID meaning. But we must remember that GUIDs are not to be confused with URLs...

Exactly.

<guid>dfgdjfhgkjsr5dwk5983479583465</guid> is interprated as that its a URL to the post, specifically that its a Permanent Link to the item. (isPermaLink defaults to true)

<guid isPermaLink=false">dfgdjfhgkjsr5dwk5983479583465</guid> is interprated that its a Unique Identifier only, it CANNOT be trusted to be a Permanent Link to the item (even if its in an URL form)

Therefor, You original statement is invalid:

how can one blame RSS readers for not being able to mark "crossposts" as read, even between two feeds from the same site.

Because the GUID's are the same, The RSS reader should understand that they're the same.

I think you may've just mis-understood the use of the isPermaLink attribute.

item.title: Ticket #9280 (<guid isPermaLink> never ever true) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
Cc changed

Yes, we know the GUID and URL are different. Smart sites purposely make them look different too.

A Guid is supposed to be Globally unique across ALL feeds

only if you mark it as true.

But you always mark it as false.

Therefore how can a reader that plays by the rules use it across ALL feeds?

Here WordPress is the authority on if what it is emitting is true or false, and it always says false... because it doesn't even trust itself?

In the case where pretty-permalinks are NOT in use

I'm afraid we're talking about two different meanings of 'permalink', the index.php?... meaning, and the RSS GUID meaning. But we must remember that GUIDs are not to be confused with URLs...

item.title: Ticket #9281 (use Last-Modified/If-Modified-Since) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
Type changed

A banner ad rotation shouldn't change a Last-Modified date.

Correct

But a site notice added to each page might.

Correct.

How is WordPress supposed to know the difference?

Simple, It doesn't, Its content from the theme or a plugin that is changing, it *doesnt* know if the content has changed, It cant keep a copy of the output and compare it later, That wouldnt work.

The difference with feeds is that once they've got the feed, they don't want it again, theres no dynamic content in the feed for them, If an ad is inserted at the end of each post, they should get the ad that they originally got, not the latest one upon a refresh (Which mind you, would also cause duplicate items in their reader.. but thats a different story).

In my opinion: If you want to use 304's for your main page, Then use a plugin, Or a Caching plugin which ends up removing any dynamic abilities WP has to start with, which means it -can- then use static content, which means it does know if it was modified.

item.title: Ticket #9281 (use Last-Modified/If-Modified-Since) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
Cc changed

Well all I know is 304 stuff is a basic web technology... all the big boys use it.

Embarrassing that WordPress can't say it the things it is emitting have changed or not.

How that is to be calculated is an internal affair.

A banner ad rotation shouldn't change a Last-Modified date.

But a site notice added to each page might.

But I would still as a rule use the same date as you do for RSS.

...and let some fancy plugin tamper with that if it insists.

item.title: Ticket #9286 (Using HTML <base> or links from site root can trim down page size) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
OK, you are right about gzip. I see. But only over the phone line: the page is still bulkier in the browser, etc.

I'll try /root linking in my theme.

item.title: Ticket #9286 (Using HTML <base> or links from site root can trim down page size) closed
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
wontfix:

gzip: not relevant to this issue

It is relevant, Using relative instead of Absolute links has the main advantage of smaller filesize to download, Gzip nullifies that advantage, as the filesize is smaller regardless (It might be a few extra bytes larger than a compressed relative link document though..)

Those who link from the site root are also generally those who's pages are accessable by multiple domains, Google's pages for example can be reached from over a 150 different domains, its the same page, its not like they have a different page for each domain.

If a user wants their theme to link from the site root, theres filters that can be used for that. Relative links do not work well at all anywhere within applications which use mod_rewrite and slashes in the url's, it gets too confusing, and when a user changes their permalink structure, it ends up in more painful places.

There's already enough people with relative link issues: ​http://core.trac.wordpress.org/search?q=relative+links&noquickjump=1&ticket=on most of them just dont understand what a relative link is, or why its not working for them, adding a <base> would only help to add to their confusion.

item.title: Ticket #9286 (Using HTML <base> or links from site root can trim down page size) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description: Cc changed

item.title: Ticket #9286 (Using HTML <base> or links from site root can trim down page size) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
In fact those people who relative link are in trouble already: ​http://codex.wordpress.org/Linking_Posts_Pages_and_Categories#Relative_Link_Examples

(gzip: not relevant to this issue. P.S., Whose webhost doesn't use it automatically already?)

Even on www.google.com's homepage, we find <form action="/search...>

As far as MediaWiki, well, they mopped up the last waste in ​https://bugzilla.wikimedia.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17538

So we see the big players link from the site root at least.

Anyway, something to look into for the long term.

item.title: Ticket #8889 (say the admin passwd has also been mailed) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
Yes the moment we see it, with all its $%*@#, we know we will only be using it once.

But you tell us to "Note that password carefully!"

So we better go get a pencil and paper and copy it down, because you never know, it might just disappear when we try to use our mouse on it... you never know.

But all along there it also is sitting in our mailbox.

But you didn't tell me.

Because you didn't know either.

So who sent it then?

The uncoordinated crew.

What if I called you and told you to copy down some mishmosh. But at the same time I sent it to you.

You would say "why didn't you tell me?" All the other programs I know tell me, but not you!

At least tell me you "might have".

item.title: Ticket #8889 (say the admin passwd has also been mailed) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
except you only need that password once, you can copy-paste it to the login form if required.

Sending it in an email is only a backup incase you forget it. As soon as you login (Actually i think the login button does it automatically..?) you should be changing the password anyway.

item.title: Ticket #8889 (say the admin passwd has also been mailed) updated
item.dc:creator: jidanni
item.description:
Well then perhaps say there

"<small>Your password will also be mailed to you, unless email is not setup on the server or the server configuration doesn't allow WordPress to send the emails.</small>"

Or just

"Your password will also be mailed to you if current configuration allows."

Otherwise the feeling is

"There you are telling me to go get a pencil and paper to copy down the %@$#!*& password, when all along you already mailed it to me. The left hand doesn't know what the right hand is doing!"

item.description: invalid

item.title: Ticket #9298 (Adapt the admin layout to a 800x600px display) updated
item.dc:creator: azaozz
item.description:
The admin works well on screens with 600x800 resolution. Move all modules under the editor and "fold" the menu. You'll have effective width of about 700px for the editor/center column.

If unsure about how to move modules, see the help (top/right) on the screen.

item.title: Ticket #8723 (Instances of same class that call variable hook first generate same ...) updated
item.dc:creator: bkrausz
item.description:
Explanation, from wp-hackers:

What about using a static var that's incremented with each read to fill wp_filter_id? That guarantees it will be unique amongst other objects. It could track class names so the id stays smaller, but I see no benefit to that...

item.title: patch.txt attached to Ticket #8723
item.dc:creator: bkrausz
item.description: Proposed patch

item.title: capture61.jpg attached to Ticket #9298
item.dc:creator: rpnpif
item.description: Inaccessible zone

item.title: Ticket #9298 (Adapt the admin layout to a 800x600px display) created
item.dc:creator: rpnpif
item.description:
Not all screen have 1024 display width, far of this. Pda, netbooks, and so on may have 800x600px width or less. More, an user may decided to set the browser window width to less than 1024px.

The last release of Wordpress has a bad layout of the administration page or in the post edit page in 800x600px. Even, if the user moves the buttons on the right part of the window, a rectangular zone under the Publish button, is inaccessible making the article edition will be difficult. It is a regression against earlier release.

item.title: Ticket #9297 (Updated List of HTTP status codes for wp_header_to_desc) created
item.dc:creator: Askapache
item.description:
Updated the list of HTTP Status Code Header Descriptions stored in the global variable $wp_header_to_desc used by the functions status_header and get_status_header_desc to include a few missing codes for 100% compliance with HTTP 1.1 protocol.

Reference

  • ​IANA Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) Status Code Registry, Oct 17, 2007
  • ​AskApache - 57 HTTP Status Codes, Jan 4, 2008
  • ​Transparent Content Negotiation in HTTP, RFC 2295, March 1998.
  • ​HTTP Extensions for Distributed Authoring -- WEBDAV, RFC 2518, February 1999.
  • ​Hypertext Transfer Protocol -- HTTP/1.1, RFC 2616, June 1999.
  • ​An HTTP Extension Framework, RFC 2774, February 2000.
  • ​Upgrading to TLS Within HTTP/1.1, RFC 2817, May 2000.
  • ​Delta encoding in HTTP, RFC 3229, January 2002.
  • ​HTTP Extensions for Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning, RFC 4918, June 2007.

item.title: Ticket #9262 (Incorrect behaviour with using the PRE tag when switching between ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
My above comment is a bit contradictory, so let me clarify a little:

If you type < into TinyMCE, it's actually creating < behind the scenes as it's WYSIWYG edit and it assumes you want < to be outputted.

item.title: Ticket #9262 (Incorrect behaviour with using the PRE tag when switching between ...) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
Keywords changed

Are you typing the fake tags into the HTML editor? If so, then the first part is to be expected as TinyMCE is stripping the bad HTML out (<pre> is not meant to escape HTML for you).

The < into < and then staying as such or whatever is a bug though. I've noticed the same thing with "&" being entered into the HTML editor and then it being converted to & after switching to TinyMCE and then back to the HTML editor. I guess that's also to be expected though as that's proper HTML even though it was inside a shortcode.

In short, ticket seems invalid.

​http://www.viper007bond.com/%27 ​http://www.viper007bond.com/2009/01/30/wordpress-admin-bar-plugin-now-distributed-with-wpmu/%27

All report 404 for me. Perhaps it's related to you having a category in your permalink structure or something.

item.title: Ticket #9286 (Using HTML <base> or links from site root can trim down page size) updated
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
-1

If you're that concerned about filesize, then gzip.

If all content was WordPress generated, then <base> would be just fine as WordPress would know it's there. However all content is not WordPress generated -- much of it (namely post content and such) comes from the user who may or may not know about the <base> tag and it's setting. If they put a relative URL in their post, it could easily be broken and not go where they expected it to go.

Not to mention I believe (but am not sure) that absolute URLs are recommended for SEO purposes.

item.title: Ticket #9296 (Settings API & Permalink Settings Page Bug) updated
item.dc:creator: jfarthing84
item.description: Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #9296 (Settings API & Permalink Settings Page Bug) created
item.dc:creator: jfarthing84
item.description: Although there is a hook in the options-permalink.php to insert custom settings, it does not actually save any custom setting which is added to that page. Instead of posting to options.php like all the other options pages, it posts to itself and only handles the form data which is built into the wordpress core. It should be implemented on that page to also store custom settings that may be hooked onto that page.

item.title:
Ticket #9094 (posts_nav_link() vs. empty

's) updated
item.dc:creator: sivel
item.description:
I'm thinking adding $before, $after args to the function may be a good way to go. You could include the <p> tags in the $before and $after which would only be output if the links are output. I need to look at the code more carefully, but seems feasible.

What is your opinion?

item.title: Ticket #9273 (Add RSS Error handling functionality to RSS Widget displays) updated
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
attachment 9273.2.diff added

  • Fixes this ticket.
  • Completes error handling for all current core usage of fetch_feed()
  • s/strstr/stristr/ to handle capitalised feed URL's past the first character(ie, it now handles feed-HTTP://SITE/ as well as feed-http://)
  • changes some crazy wp-includes logic for the rss.png icon for the RSS Widget
    • I dont know why it expects the custom rss.png to be in /wp-includes/ to start with.. Eitherway, The new code is readable..

item.title: Ticket #9290 (unable to do automatic upgrade over SFTP (ssh+ftp)) closed
item.dc:creator: DD32
item.description:
worksforme:

Yes, If you install the PHP SSH2 extension, It can upgrade via SFTP.

I'm closing this as worksforme, As if you've got the required modules installed, It works.

There are some known issues, eg: #8120

This isn't a support forum however, So if you have any problems with the basic instructions in the file, you'll have to seek support for it elsewhere (Preferably PHP support forums possibly, I'm not sure how much luck you'll have with the WordPress support forums - although there might be a few there who can help)
